results.title: Werckmeister harmonies. Damnation = Werckmeister harmoniak. Karhozat
results.creator_credit: Bela Tarr, Franz Goess, Joachim von Vietinghoff, Josef Marx, Miklos Szita, Paul Saadoun, 13 Productions, Goess Films, Magyar Filmintezet, Magyar Televizio, Mokep and Von Vietinghoff Filmproduktion
results.brief_description: Werckmeister harmonies: Haunting and atmospheric, this slow-moving narrative filmed in stark black and white reflects the harsh political environment that is Eastern Europe. The main character, Jancos (Lars Rudolph), a visionary and an outsider is drawn to the arrival in his bleak provincial town on the Hungarian plains, of a circus featuring the stuffed carcass of a massive dead whale and a mysterious, somewhat sinister figure called “The Prince”. What follows this arrival into this already economically depressed village is quite disturbing. Using long and lingering shots, the images create nuances and subtleties that make “Werckmeister harmonies” an intriguing and beautiful film. Cast also includes Peter Fitz, Hanna Schygulla. Based on “The Melancholy of Resistance” by Laszlo Krasznahorkai. “Damnation”: Featuring Bela Tarr’s renowned long takes and bleak black and white images, this story follows Karrer (Miklos B. Szekely), a sullen and listless man obsessed with a married woman (Vali Kerekes) who sings at a local bar, the Titanik. Betrayal and conflict eventually lead to despair for Karrer and alienation from those around him. Extremely slow, beautifully photographed and quite depressing but definitely compelling. Cast also includes Gyula Pauer, Gyorgy Cserhalmi. A collaboration with writer Laszlo Krasznahorkai.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bela Tarr, Franz Goess, Joachim von Vietinghoff, Josef Marx, Miklos Szita, Paul Saadoun, 13 Productions, Goess Films, Magyar Filmintezet, Magyar Televizio, Mokep and Von Vietinghoff Filmproduktion

results.title: Tobacco wars
results.creator_credit: Derek Jones, Ros Franey and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description: While the sale of cigarettes has decreased significantly on the Western market, worldwide consumption of cigarettes has increased markedly since the push of tobacco giants R.J. Reynolds and Philip Morris to export to Asia. Presented by the British current affairs team at “First Tuesday,” this program looks at the human cost of cigarette smoking and the war that is being waged between health and trade. Narrator Michael Crocker explains the relationship between advertising in Asia, cigarette sales and the incidence of cancer, brand stretching to bypass advertising bans and the role of government heavy weights in lobbying on behalf of the tobacco industry. Features interviews with cigarette models Janet Sackman and Wayne (Marlboro Man) McLaren, both of whom have earned notoriety for their role in cigarette advertising as well as cancer attributed to their nicotine addiction. Presented by Olivia O’Leary.

results.title: Toast
results.brief_description: Focuses on the excessive use of fossil fuels in the preparation and marketing of food by tracing the production and distribution of a loaf of bread. Also illustrates the concept of net energy profit.

results.title: Wings to Guatemala
results.creator_credit: Jean Oser, Stanley Toogood and International Film Productions
results.brief_description: A brief history of Guatemala is presented. The descendents of the Mayan Indians are shown on the shores of Lake Atillan, living a life that is largely based on ancient tradition. They work for six days on Chichicastenango to sell their goods and workshop their old Mayan gods on the steps on the church. Scenes are included of the modern city of Guatemala and the luxurious resorts set among the ruins of the past. The fondness of the people for music and traditional dancing is shown.

results.title: Wings to Central America and Mexico
results.brief_description: The scenery, industries, and life and customs of the inhabitants of the seven Central American countries, Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, San Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Panama. South American Indians constitute a large percentage of the populations and the influence of the old Maya gods and the Spanish conquistadors influences their religion and their dances. The Panama Canal and lie in sophisticated Bilboa which is an opulent cosmopolitan city are shown. In Mexico there is a sharp contrast between life in the country and in Mexico City with its modern buildings as well as the architecture of old Colonial Spain. A popular pastime is bullfighting.

results.title: Wings of Honneamise
results.creator_credit: Hiroyuki Yamaga, Hiroaki Inoue, Hirohiko Sueyoshi and Manga Entertainment
results.brief_description: An epic tale charting civilisation’s fascination with reaching the stars. Apathetic student Shirotsugu Lhadatt winds up in the Royal Space Force after bad grades destroy his dreams of entering the local airforce. Unfortunately, the Royal Space Force is little more than a motley group of young cadets and ageing scientists struggling to send man into space while suffering public ridicule, government wrangling, and a lack of resources. However, after Shiro crosses paths with devout missionary, Riquinni, he becomes determined to be the first man in space. Spurred on by his unrequited love for her, Shiro braves assassins, funding crises and the threat of war to make his dream of travelling to the stars a reality. A stunningly animated feature film. Some subtitles.

results.title: Twelfth night: or what you will [Nunn]
results.creator_credit: Trevor Nunn, David Parfitt, Stephen Evans, Fine Line Features and Twelfth Night Productions
results.brief_description: Trevor Nunn’s faithful adaptation of Shakespeare’s tale of love, deception and gender stars Ben Kingley, Helena Bonham Carter, Nigel Hawthorn, Richard E Grant, Imogen Stubbs, Mel Smith, Imelda Staunton and Toby Stephens. A brother and sister are separated in a shipwreck and land on the shore of Illyria. The sister Viola (Stubbs) disguises herself as a man and takes service with Duke Orsino (Stephens) who has fallen passionately in love with Lady Olivia (Bonham Carter). Viola is entrusted to plead on her master’s behalf and finds that Olivia has fallen madly in love with her. Thus begins the comedy of deception which has delighted audiences for centuries.

results.title: Twelfth night: or what you will
results.creator_credit: Kenneth Branagh, Paul Kafno, David Parfitt, Renaissance Theatre Company and Thames Video
results.brief_description: This is the Renaissance Theatre Company’s production of the play directed by Kenneth Branagh. The cast is led by Richard Briers as Malvolio and Caroline Langrishe as Viola. A brother and sister are separated in a shipwreck and land on the shore of Illyria. The sister Viola disguises herself as a man and takes service with Duke Orsino who has fallen passionately in love with Lady Olivia. Viola is entrusted to plead on her master’s behalf and finds that Olivia has fallen madly in love with her. Thus begins the comedy of deception which has delighted audiences for centuries.

results.title: Phenakistiscope disc (Politeness)
results.brief_description: The phenakistoscope is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc is fitted to the device and when seen through the slots, comes to life.
results.description:
This is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc featuring a sequence of slightly different pictures is mounted on a handle. Around the disc’s rim, above the images, are equally spaced slots. Nothing magical happens when you spin the disc, but the images flicker to life when you peer through the slots at the disc’s reflection in a mirror.

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistoscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.
description_for_label:

Around the disc’s rim, above the images, are equally spaced slots. Nothing magical happens when you spin the disc, but the images flicker to life when you peer through the slots at the disc’s reflection in a mirror.

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistoscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.
